intro: Draba barclayana, commonly known as the Barclay’s whitlow grass, is a low-growing perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It typically reaches heights of 5 to 15 centimeters and features a basal rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers in early spring, which are clustered in dense inflorescences. Its flowers are typically 5-lobed and have four to five stamens. Draba barclayana is adapted to rocky and alpine environments, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun.
